title: reinforcements for both falcons and lions

author: Gus_263
title: The classic castle minifigure pack
review: This set was released in the year of 1985, in the castle theme. So, it includes some minifigures with characteristics of the classic castle theme. The six minifigures are from the black falcons or the lion knights, making some additions to the army of these. There are three lion knights, these are basic and simple designed, but it still cool due to the color schemes and classic Lego style. Each of these three lion knights looks like to be the same, but it makes a good effect for the army, and it looks like to be more original from Lego. The lion knights features red, blue and black schemes (the black are on details, and also the yellow, in the skin, and in the symbol of the lion). The lion knights includes two shields, two helmets, and another with different shape, also a axe and a longbow. The knights that features the blue, white and black colors are the original black falcon knights. The three of this army are also, basically, the same. But these have three helmets (one with a different shape), two shields, one longbow, one axe and spear. These original knights increased with weapons, shields and helmets are additions to any castle army, and were cheap in that times, because now are rarities. In comparison with other minifigure packs, it gets a 5/5.

author: CamberbrickGreen
title: Clang! Clang! Clatter! Clang!
review:
Its the castle booster set equally best described as a battle in a box.

The Black Falcons
(They always appeared like Ravens to me?) are more defensively armed with;
  • Archer: black pointy helmet, bow and arrow with quiver, 
  • Guard: black skirted helmet, brown spear and blue lined shield.
  • Guard: black pointy helmet, brown axe, yellow lined shield.
They often sported red 'leather belts' but this is a good varied colour scheme for an otherwise very black, leathery design. Nice black and silvery torso prints as usual with the army badge,

The Lion Knights
Their feel is more offensive.
  • Archer: grey pointy helmet, bow, arrow and quiver.
  • Guard: grey skirted helmet, black axe and a proper blue shield with yellow lion.
  • Knight: To my mind only a knight's helmet makes a knight but gets a grey pointy helmet and a yellow shield with blue lion.
There are two lion badge torsos and one crossed axes one which stands out more uniquely in beautiful goldy bronze and brown. I always found the original blue shield smart while the yellow unattractive, a red lion on blue with yellow trim seeming a more suitable reverse. Black leather belts seem mostly standard to the lion army on their rather bright blue trousers (grey would have been great).

As with all shields they could get snapped or have their print scraped off over time so these are pieces to look after, the prints are excellent all round. Sadly no flags in these minifigure boxes, which always enhanced the theme.

Retreat!
Of course all parts were interchangeable for each character. A later Castle people set was preferable as was the missed option of a circular shield but this is the earlier box that retains plenty of merit just for the inception of the theme.

author: SiaFu
title: Way before battle packs
review:
This was my first LEGO set, and the first one I ever saw.
The minifigs were a marvel compared to other toys regarding their articulation, the quality of insignia printing and supplied weapons/accessories. And minifigs are what this set is all about - 6 knights, 3 vs 3, almost fairly matched (archer and battle-axe on each side, leaving sword vs spear). Four different shields and different torso prints that allow individuality while clearly distinguishing the Lions and the Falcons. No filler parts or scenery you might not want, just the battle-ready minifig troops.
Simple to build, and duplicate sets are not an issue as you can swap the pieces around if you don't want uniformity for your troops.

Too bad there aren't modern LEGO Castle sets like this. It's either one minifig plus some accessories and scenery or a pre-built blister pack with a comparatively bigger price than this set had back in the '80s (when each minifig was worth about four unpainted 1:72 Italieri miniature soldiers).

author: Niki124
title: Very useful addition
review: One thing I liked about Castle Minifigures is that there are more unique figures than you may think, despite everyone looking like a coherently-dressed army. This set is a nice showcase of the different styles used, and of the variety of weapons which came as accessories with these sets at the time. The only issue I recall is that the larger bell-shaped helmets had a tendency to come away easily, they would often get caught on something along the edge.
